header: IIIEnd-Effector Radius Modeling and Wheel Contact Compensation

images.caption: Figure 5:Sagittal-plane model of a rounded point foot.O1O_{1}is the shank–foot connection. Touchdown and lift-off shank pitch angles area1a_{1}anda2a_{2}. Ignoring rolling yields the fictitious displacementO1→O3O_{1}\!\rightarrow\!O_{3}, while hemispherical rolling yields the physical displacementO1→O2O_{1}\!\rightarrow\!O_{2}.

Figure 6:Rolling-contact modeling bias forR=0.03R=0.03m and touchdown pitcha1=80∘a_{1}=80^{\circ}, witha2∈[60∘,140∘]a_{2}\in[60^{\circ},140^{\circ}]. The curves plotΔx\Delta_{x}(red) andΔz\Delta_{z}(blue) from (18).

header: IVInverse-Kinematics Cubature Kalman Filtering for Foot-End Velocity

images.caption: Figure 7:Estimated body linear velocity. Red/green/blue correspond tovxv_{x},vyv_{y}, andvzv_{z}. Without IKVel-CKF, the horizontal channels exhibit large impulsive errors (up to∼\sim200% of nominal magnitude). With IKVel-CKF enabled, the spikes are strongly suppressed (within∼\sim25% of nominal magnitude).

Figure 8:Representative hip–foot velocity feedback (leg 1). Blue: raw forward-kinematics velocity using encoder-derived joint rates. Red: IKVel-CKF filtered velocity. IKVel-CKF effectively removes impulsive spikes; the zoomed view shows a modest smoothing-induced lag, trading a small phase delay for substantially improved robustness.

header: VKinematics-Based Yaw Estimation via Multi-Contact Geometric Consistency

images.caption: Figure 9:Illustration of the geometric cue exploited for yaw correction. The blue model denotes the initial configuration and the yellow model denotes the twisted trunk pose while feet remain fixed. With multi-contact, the world-frame inter-foot geometry stays constant, enabling a kinematics-derived heading reference.
Figure 10:Locomotion trajectories in simulation. The flat-ground loop is shown in blue and the stair-climbing loop in red.
